title: 108_s869
content: The "Assure Access to Mammography Act of 2003" enhances reimbursement under the Medicare program for screening and diagnostic mammography services provided in 2003. The "Assure Access to Mammography Act of 2003" increases Medicare reimbursement for screening and diagnostic mammography services provided at hospital-based facilities to 200 percent of the fee schedule amount. The "Assure Access to Mammography Act of 2003" increases Medicare reimbursement for screening or diagnostic mammography at hospital-based facilities during a specific period, not under section 1833(t) of the Act. The applicable period starts from the enactment of the Act until the Secretary establishes a payment rate under the prospective payment system for outpatient services. The "Assure Access to Mammography Act of 2003" defines a hospital-based facility as one receiving payment for mammography under a specific section. For a certain period, additional radiology residents are not counted towards graduate medical education limitations for hospitals. The "Assure Access to Mammography Act of 2003" excludes additional radiology residents from graduate medical education limitations for hospitals if the number exceeds the previous reporting period. This exemption applies to each year of the resident's training program in radiology. The "Assure Access to Mammography Act of 2003" exempts additional radiology residents from graduate medical education limitations for hospitals if the number exceeds the previous reporting period. SEC. 3. IOM study and report on Medicare reimbursement for gender-specific services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will arrange for a study by the Institute of Medicine to assess the relative value units for gender-specific physician services under the medicare physician fee schedule. The study will also look into payment adjustments for gender-specific services in inpatient hospital and skilled nursing facility settings. The Institute will submit a report on the study to the Secretary. The Institute will submit a report to the Secretary by December 31, 2004, with recommendations on adjusting relative value units for physicians' services and payment amounts for gender-specific services in hospitals and skilled nursing facilities. The Secretary will then transmit the report to Congress promptly. MEDPAC will study Medicare reimbursement for screening services and submit a report to Congress by March 1, 2004, with recommendations on adjusting relative value units for these services.
